unnormalised: Someone asked me about the difference between Capt. and Col. – and honestly, it’s less about strategy and more about survival! Think of it this way: Capt. Sharma is just trying to get through his shift without someone accidentally saluting the tea vendor again. Col. Verma, on the other hand, is trying to figure out how to explain why the battalion’s budget mysteriously disappeared and all that's left is a lifetime supply of samosas.
normalised: Someone asked me about the difference between Captain and Colonel – and honestly, it’s less about strategy and more about survival! Think of it this way: Captain Sharma is just trying to get through his shift without someone accidentally saluting the tea vendor again. Colonel Verma, on the other hand, is trying to figure out how to explain why the battalion’s budget mysteriously disappeared and all that's left is a lifetime supply of samosas.

unnormalised: Seriously though, a Capt. usually commands a company – maybe 100-250 soldiers. Lots of paperwork, keeping track of who’s pretending to be sick to avoid PT, and ensuring everyone knows the mess schedule. A Col., or Colonel, is usually in charge of a regiment or brigade – think thousands of troops. They're dealing with bigger picture stuff: maneuvers, logistics, and convincing the Gen. that their "innovative" camouflage idea involving tie-dye sarees is totally legit.
normalised: Seriously though, a Captain usually commands a company – maybe one hundred to two hundred and fifty soldiers. Lots of paperwork, keeping track of who’s pretending to be sick to avoid P-T, and ensuring everyone knows the mess schedule. A Colonel, or Colonel, is usually in charge of a regiment or brigade – think thousands of troops. They're dealing with bigger picture stuff: maneuvers, logistics, and convincing the General that their "innovative" camouflage idea involving tie-dye sarees is totally legit.

unnormalised: So, next time you see a Brig. or a Lt. Gen., remember they’ve climbed the ladder of military might. They've probably earned enough stripes to quilt a king-size bed. Whether it’s a Subedar or a Naik, just salute smartly, say "Jai Hind!", and hope they don’t ask you to do push-ups. Especially if you've just eaten 5 samosas.
